title: See How Much RAM You Have on PC, Mac, Chromebook, & iPad

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Open Settings .
steps.content: Open Settings . Click the gear-shaped icon in the lower-left side of the Start window. This will open the Settings window. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click System.
steps.content: Click System . It's a laptop-shaped icon in the upper-left side of the window. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click the About tab.
steps.content: Click the About tab. You'll find this in the lower-left corner of the System window. This opens a list of information about your computer. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Review the "Installed RAM" section.
steps.content: Review the "Installed RAM" section. It's in the "Device specifications" section near the middle of the page. The number to the right of the "Installed RAM" heading indicates how much RAM your PC has installed.

steps.title: Check your computer's RAM usage
steps.content: Check your computer's RAM usage . If you want to see how your PC is using its RAM (or how much it's using at a given point in time), you can use the Task Manager program to do so. Doing this while running a program will give you an idea of how much RAM the program needs to run properly.

steps.title: Press Ctrl+⇧ Shift+Esc to open the Task Manager.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + ⇧ Shift + Esc to open the Task Manager. This will show you a menu with every task running on your computer. Here, you can check your memory usage. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the Memory column.
steps.content: Look at the Memory column. The percentage in the header tells you how much of your RAM you’re using at a given moment. The numbers in the column give the exact amount of memory a process is using. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Click the performance button in the right-side menu.
steps.content: Click the performance button in the right-side menu. This opens the performance tab of the Task Manager.

steps.title: Click Memory.
steps.content: Click Memory . This will show you how much RAM your computer is using and how much it has total. The number may be smaller than your PC’s nominal RAM. This might be because some RAM is dedicated to system tasks not shown in Task Manager, or because some RAM is reserved by hardware in your system.

steps.title: Look at the RAM specifications.
steps.content: Look at the RAM specifications. You can see the following RAM attributes in the Memory section of the Performance tab: Speed - the rated speed for your installed RAM. Slots used - how many RAM slots currently have RAM installed. For example, you might have two 4 GB RAM sticks installed on your computer, making for a total of 8 GB of RAM. Form factor - the type of RAM installed on your computer. Hardware reserved - this is memory that has been reserved by hardware in your computer.

steps.title: Open the Apple menu .
steps.content: Open the Apple menu . Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Click About This Mac.
steps.content: Click About This Mac . It's in the drop-down menu. Doing so opens the About This Mac window. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Overview tab.
steps.content: Click the Overview tab. This tab is in the upper-left side of the About This Mac window. The Overview tab will usually open by default when you open About This Mac.

steps.title: Review the "Memory" heading.
steps.content: Review the "Memory" heading. The number to the right of the "Memory" heading indicates how much RAM your Mac has installed, as well as what type of RAM you're using.

steps.title: Check your Mac's RAM usage
steps.content: Check your Mac's RAM usage . If you want to see how your Mac is using its RAM (or how much it's using at a given point in time), you can use the Activity Monitor program to do so. [9] X Research source Doing this while running a program will give you an idea of how much RAM the program needs to run properly.

steps.title: Open Google Chrome.
steps.content: Open Google Chrome. This is the default web browser on Chromebooks. It's the icon with a red, green, and yellow circle surrounding a smaller blue circle.

steps.title: Type chrome://system in the URL bar.
steps.content: Type chrome://system in the URL bar. Then, press enter to open the system specifications page.

steps.title: Click Expand next to “meminfo.”
steps.content: Click Expand next to “meminfo.” This will open a list showing you a breakdown of your Chromebook’s memory.

steps.title: Find your iPad’s model number.
steps.content: Find your iPad’s model number. This is typically located on the back cover of the device. You’ll use this to find the technical specifications (tech specs) for your tablet.

steps.title: Go to https://support.apple.com/en-us/108043.
steps.content: Go to https://support.apple.com/en-us/108043 . This official Apple website lists every iPad’s model number.

steps.title: Find your iPad model.
steps.content: Find your iPad model. You can use your web browser’s find feature to locate the model number. The shortcut on Windows PCs to find text on a webpage is usually ctrl + f . For macOS, it’s typically cmd + f . On mobile web browsers, the find feature can be found in the More menu.

steps.title: Click “tech specs for <iPad Model>.”
steps.content: Click “tech specs for <iPad Model>.” Where <iPad Model> is the model name for your tablet. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Scroll down to the Chip section.
steps.content: Scroll down to the Chip section. This is where your model’s RAM amount can be found. Alternatively, you can try the Smart Memory Lite app for iPad. It shows you the tablet’s total RAM and memory usage.
